Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Recovery and Adjustment in the Community after Hurricane Florence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Severe natural disasters carry great economic costs and threaten individuals' health and well-being in both the short and longer-term. Severe natural disasters during the past decade include unprecedented flooding, devastating wildfires, and catastrophic hurricanes. On September 14, 2018, Hurricane Florence made landfall off the coast of Wilmington, North Carolina, causing billions of dollars in damage to the state and surrounding region. Robeson County was one of the hardest hit counties in North Carolina, with catastrophic flooding causing substantial damage to residences, businesses, and infrastructure. The same county had experienced widespread damage following Hurricane Matthew in 2016 as well. Many in the hardest hit areas were still experiencing long-term impacts from Hurricane Matthew in 2018, including loss of employment and physical health problems related to exposure to mold and other contaminants. Research focused on the experiences of individuals in this county offers a unique opportunity to better understand how individuals cope with and recover from severe and ongoing stress in the post-disaster context. This project seeks to gain a richer understanding of how individuals manage post-disaster recovery and the extent to which individual and social factors predict both positive and negative outcomes. By integrating theories of post-disaster adjustment and using advanced data analytic techniques, the current study will lead to a better understanding of individual and community responses to extreme events and inform the development of future interventions.

Online surveys and daily "check in" assessments administered via smart phone technology will be used to study psychological adjustment, social support, community solidarity, and coping efforts among adult residents of Robeson County, North Carolina who were exposed to severe and repeated hurricane-related stress. The surveys and the daily "check-ins" will provide critical data on how people cope with stress over time, including the extent to which social and individual factors affect adjustment. By cultivating a very rich set of data on the same individuals over time, it will be possible to discern patterns of recovery, and understanding which we are currently lacking. Measuring outcomes on a daily basis will generate significant amounts of data and we will use advanced non-linear data analysis methods to identify unique changes or shifts in functioning predicted by guiding theoretical frameworks (self-regulation shift theory and social support deterioration deterrence theory). This project extends current knowledge related to post-disaster recovery by targeting key social and coping mechanisms of change and highlighting possible critical targets for interventions in the near and long-term post disaster context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impact of natural disasters such as Hurricane Florence, which made landfall in North Carolina in September of 2018, includes both economic costs, as well as mental and physical health impacts. It is estimated that the economic impact alone of Hurricane Florence to North Carolina topped 17 billion dollars. Rural counties in the Sandhills region of North Carolina were some of the hardest hit in the state, with catastrophic flooding causing substantial damage to residences, businesses, and infrastructure. Notably, many individuals in this area were still experiencing long-term impacts from Hurricane Matthew which caused significant damage to the region in 2016. These long-term impacts include loss of employment, physical health problems related to exposure to contaminants, and stress-related mental health impacts.

The current study sought to better understand how individuals cope with and recover from severe and ongoing stress following hurricanes through a longitudinal study of Hurricane Florence survivors from the Sandhills region of NC. The overarching goal of this project was to gain a richer understanding of how individuals manage post-disaster recovery and the extent to which individual and social factors predict outcomes. By integrating theories of post-disaster adjustment and using advanced data analytic techniques, the current study sought to lead to a better understanding of individual and community responses to extreme events and inform the development of future interventions to serve those who are affected by disasters.

 The study involved 261 individuals residing in four rural counties in the Sandhills region of North Carolina who were recruited into the study 5 to 8 months post Hurricane Florence. Participants experienced high levels of hurricane-related stress including mold damage to their home, exposure to contamination, loss of possessions, and the development or worsening of a health condition as a result of exposure to contamination. All participants reported experiencing ongoing daily impacts from the hurricane when they enrolled in the study. They completed three online surveys about their social support, hurricane-related coping and coping self-efficacy, self-compassion, and hurricane-related distress, completing one survey every three months. They also completed brief daily questions about their hurricane-related stress, coping, and social support, using an app on their phone for a period of six weeks.

Initial analyses of the results support several key findings consistent with extant theories of post-disaster adjustment. For one, receiving support from others in the aftermath of the hurricane was related to improvements in both one’s connection with the community and hurricane-related distress. Further, individuals who believed that they could successfully cope with the hurricane and its aftermath, that is those with high coping self-efficacy, were more likely to experience decreases in hurricane-related distress over time.  Finally, people who were higher in self-compassion, which is defined as being kind to oneself in the face of shortcomings or failures, reported better overall well-being and more adaptive hurricane-related coping. In addition, they were able to maintain positive perceptions of their supportive relationships with others, even if they did not receive as much help from others in managing the hurricane.

This project extends what is currently understood related to post-disaster recovery by targeting key social and coping mechanisms of change and highlighting possible critical targets for interventions in the near and long-term post disaster context.
